Here is the favorites activity that extends fragment.

What you are about to engage in is the opportunity to progress your current daily behavioral patterns. You have found yourself here because at some point you knew you could do better and be better as a human being in life.
In no way does this app diagnose, cure or counsel it\'s users. In every way, does this app advocate and cheer you on in the direction you know you need to go.
Try studying while moving or exercising
Try using physical motions to articulate vocabulary and key concepts
Try to draw or write things in the air as you think about them
Write concepts/terms down in your own words
Act out the any concepts you need to remember
Utilize manipulative and interactive web material to master difficult concepts
Look for real-life examples that demonstrate what you’re learning about
Create a song, rap, or rhyme that will help you remember difficult concepts
Listen to instrumental music while you study
Remember vocabulary words by linking them to similar-sounding words in your mind
Read text and notes aloud and repeat when it doesn’t makes sense
Try saying concepts or definitions aloud with your eyes closed
create a Music Video
Try to be in or near nature when studying
Try to connect vocabulary to nature
Organize chapter notes into an outline (roman numeral style)
Transform your notes into numeric charts, graphs, and tables.
Put information you receive into categories and classifications that you create
Compare/contrast previously learned items with new concepts (rock cycle vs. carbon and nitrogen cycles)
Formulate analogies to describe abstract or complex ideas
Devise a mnemonic device to help remember methods or multi-faceted definitions/terms
Discuss what you learn with a friend or family member
Have someone quiz you before an exam
Create or join a study group
Go over section assessment chapter test questions from book with others
Avoid being alone when you try to study (only if your intrapersonal intelligence is weak)
Read about or watch videos on others’ ideas on difficult topics (Google, YouTube, etc.)
Share ideas with friends
Partake in the Extra Credit Music Video Assignment with some friends
Sketch pictures that go along with your notes or in the margins of your textbooks
Draw a picture on a flashcard for each concept or vocabulary word you study
Design charts, tables, diagrams, foldables, and/or other graphic organizers to organize and keep track of what you learn
Picture images and scenarios in your mind to associate with different concepts and ideas
Re-watch videos from class
Make visual flash cards to study vocabulary and key concepts
Find a place to study alone where you won’t be interrupted (avoid group studying)
Study in quiet places(unless your musical intelligence in high in which case light instrumentals may help)
Talk to yourself or an inanimate object about key concepts
Reflect upon and correct handouts, book questions, and study guide by yourself
Use google to complete self-check quizzes for each section
Keep a daily personal journal on what you learn
Make flashcards for vocabulary AND key concepts (speak aloud when self-quizzing)
Read textbook, notes (ones you took in class and from PowerPoint on website), handouts, etc. (repeat if necessary)
Take extra notes on tougher parts of chapter(s)
Rewrite key concepts and definitions
Orally summarize section to another person (friend, parent, etc.)
Re-organize class notes
Orally recite definitions and key concepts

Home Screen

GOT IT
Welcome To Conscious
The easiest way to impact your current intelligence and build different types of intelligence types!
Build Multiple Intelligences
Introduce yourself to the different ways you can impact your brain by understanding how you can upgrade it!
Learn From Growth Challenges
Interact with challenges for specific intelligence types and allow yourself to track + maintain your growth goals !
Track Personal Challenges
Frequently keep track of your progress towards your self defined goals to increase your chances of success
To see the welcome slider again, goto Settings -> apps -> welcome slider -> clear data
Play Again

Body smart people work well with their hands. You enjoy physical activity such as exercise, sports, and outdoor work.
Write concepts/terms down in your own words
Act out the concepts you need to remember
Look for real-life examples that demonstrate what you’re learning about
Utilize manipulatives and interactive web material to master difficult concepts
Try studying while moving or exercising
Use physical motions to articulate vocabulary and key concepts
Draw or write things in the air as you think about them
Music smart people are good with rhythms and beats. You enjoy listening to music, attending concerts, and creating songs
Create a song, rap, or rhyme that will help you remember difficult concepts
Listen to instrumental music while you study
Remember vocabulary words by linking them to similar-sounding words in your mind
Read text and notes aloud and repeat when it doesn’t makes sense
Try saying concepts or definitions aloud with your eyes closed
Nature smart people enjoy learning about the world of plants and animals. You generally like science and enjoy learning outdoors if the weather suits it.
Try to be in or near nature when studying
Try to connect vocabulary to nature
Number smart people are good with numbers, logic, and equations. You enjoy coming up with solutions to logical problems and figuring things out.
Organize chapter notes into an outline (roman numeral style)
Transform your notes into numeric charts, graphs, and tables.
Put information you receive into categories and classifications that you create
Compare/contrast previously learned items with new concepts (rock cycle vs. carbon & nitrogen cycles)
Formulate analogies to describe abstract or complex ideas
Devise a mnemonic device to help remember methods or multi-faceted definitions/terms
Those who are people smart are good with relating to people. You enjoy going to parties, visiting with friends, and sharing what you learn
Discuss what you learn with a friend or family member
Have someone quiz you before an exam
Create or join a study group
Go over section assessment chapter test questions from book with others
Avoid being alone when you try to study (only if your intrapersonal intelligence is weak)
Read about or watch videos on others’ ideas on difficult topics (Google, YouTube, etc.)
Share ideas with friends
Picture smart people are good with art and design. You enjoy being creative, watching movies, and visiting art museums
Sketch pictures that go along with your notes or in the margins of your textbooks
Draw a picture on a flashcard for each concept or vocabulary word you study
Design charts, tables, diagrams, foldables, and/or other graphic organizers to organize and keep track of what you learn
Picture images and scenarios in your mind to associate with different concepts and ideas
Re-watch videos from class
Make visual flash cards to study vocabulary and key concepts
Self smart people are comfortable with themselves. You enjoy being alone to think and reflect.
Find a place to study alone where you won’t be interrupted (avoid group studying)
Study in quiet places(unless your musical intelligence in high in which case light instrumentals may help)
Talk to yourself or an inanimate object about key concepts
Reflect upon and correct handouts, book questions, and study guide by yourself
Keep a daily personal journal on what you learn
Word smart people are good with words, letters, and phrases. You enjoy activities such as reading, playing scrabble or other word games, and having discussions.
Make flashcards for vocabulary AND key concepts (speak aloud when self-quizzing)
Read textbook, notes (ones you took in class and from PowerPoint on website), handouts, etc. (repeat if necessary)
Take extra notes on tougher parts of chapter(s)
Rewrite key concepts and definitions
Orally summarize section to another person (friend, parent, etc.)
Re-organize class notes
Orally recite definitions and key concepts
